item.title: Notes on Institutions, Contract & Information
item.description: Literature Adverse Selection (Hidden Information) Lemon Market Moral Hazard (Hidden Action) Benchmark Limited Liability Literature Contract Theory Game Theory (multi-stage games) Institutions and Economic Theory (very general and theoretical) Institutional Economics: An Introduction (Groenewegen, J. & Spithoven, A. & Van den Berg, A.) Firms, contracts, and financial structure (incomplete contract) Adverse Selection (Hidden Information) Lemon Market Moral Hazard (Hidden Action) Contract payment: \(t\) Principle’s return: \(v\in \{v_H, v_L\}\) (verifiable, random) Effort level: \(e\in \{ e_H, e_L\}\) (unobservable) Agent’s effort cost: \(c(e)\) Let probability that \(v\) realize be \[\begin{aligned}Pr( v = v_H \ | \ e = e_H ) &= e_H \\ Pr( v = v_H \ | \ e=e_L ) & = e_L \\ e_L &< eH \end{aligned}\] Reservation utility: \(\underline{U} = 0\) Incentive compatility constraint (IC): agent chooses the level of effort that maximizes their own utility Participation constraint (PC): agent accepts the contract only if the expected utility exceeds other alternatives (their reservation utility) Benchmark First best solution: \[e^{FB} = \text{argmax} \ E[v \ | \ e] - c(e)\] Franchising contract: \(t(v) = v-a\) Agent’s payoff \[\begin{aligned}E[t(v) \ | \ e] - c(e) &= E[v \ | \ e] - a - c(e) \\ &\geq \underline{U} \\ &= 0 \end{aligned}\] Principle’s payoff \[a = E[v \ | \ e^{FB}] - c(e^{FB})\] Limited Liability Let Agent’s effort cost be \(\begin{cases}c(e_H) = c \\ c(e_L) = 0 \end{cases}\) First best solution \(e^{FB} = e_H\) when \[\begin{aligned} e_H v_H - (1-e_H )v_L - c &\geq e_Lv_H + (1-e_L)v_L \\ (e_H - e_L)(v_H - v_L) &\geq c\end{aligned}\] \(e^{FB} = e_L\) otherwise Second best solution Contract: \(\begin{cases}t(v_H) = t_H \\ t(v_L) = t_L \end{cases}\) When principle wants to implement \(e = e_H\) \[\begin{aligned}\max && &e_H(v_H - t_H) + (1-e_H)(v_L - t_L) \\ (IC) && &e_H t_H - (1-e_H )t_L - c \geq e_L t_H - (1-e_L )t_L - 0 \\ (PC) && &e_H t_H - (1-e_H )t_L - c \geq \underline{U} = 0 \\ (LL) && &\begin{cases}t_H \geq 0 \\t_L \geq 0 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\] Lemma: \(\begin{cases}t_H = \frac{c}{e_H - e_L} \\ t_L = 0\end{cases}\) is a solution

item.title: Notes on Game Theory
item.description: Extensive Game, Perfect Information Strategy Subgame Chance Moves Bargaining textbook 1: (OR) A Course in Game Theory textbook 2: (BM) Fun and games Reference: Carlos Hurtado’s lecture notes Extensive Game, Perfect Information OR 6.1 Reference Set of players: \(N\) Set of histories: \(H\) History (sequence): \(h = (a^k)_{k=1}^K\) Initial history: \(\emptyset\in H\) \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\), \(K>L\implies (a^k)_{k=1}^L\in H\) \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) for all \(K\in\mathbb{N} \implies (a^k)_{k=1}^{\infty}\in H\) Set of terminal histories: \(Z\) Terminal history: \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) is terminal if exists no \((a^k)_{k=1}^{K+1}\in H\) Set of (possible) actions: \(A(h): \{ a \ | \ (h,a)\in H\}\) Action: \(a\in h\) for some \(k\in K\) History of length \(k+1\): \((h,a)\) Player function: \(P: (H\backslash Z)\to N\) Player to move after history \(h\): \(P(h)\) Initial player: \(P(\emptyset)\) with \(a^0\in A(\emptyset)\) Second player: \(P(a^0)\) with \(a^1\in A(a^0)\) Preference relation: \(\succsim_i\) defined on \(Z\) Extensive Game with Perfect Information: \[Γ = \langle N,H,P,(\succsim_i)\rangle\text{ or }\langle N,H,P\rangle\] Finite game: \(|H|<\infty\) Finite horizon: \(K <\infty\) for all \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) Rank of game: \(\max K\) for all \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) Length of game: \(l(Γ)\) is the length of longest history in \(Γ\) Exercise (slides P13)
